overview:
## Discussion

When you need a range that includes the last element of an array, use the half-open range operator (`..<`) with [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex]. The `..<` operator creates a range that doesn’t include the upper bound, so it’s safe to use with [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex].

If the array is empty, [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex] is equal to [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/startIndex].

# endIndex

**Instance Property**

The position one greater than the last valid subscript argument.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor @preconcurrency var endIndex: Int { get }
```

## Discussion

When you need a range that includes the last element of an array, use the half-open range operator (`..<`) with [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex]. The `..<` operator creates a range that doesn’t include the upper bound, so it’s safe to use with [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex].

If the array is empty, [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/endIndex] is equal to [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/Scene/AnchorCollection/startIndex].

## Manipulating indices

- **Scene.AnchorCollection.Index**: A type that represents a position in the collection.
- **Scene.AnchorCollection.Indices**: A type that represents the indices that are valid for subscripting the collection, in ascending order.
- **startIndex**: The position of the first element in a nonempty collection.
- **index(after:)**: Returns the position immediately after the given index.
